coredata.dc:title: Localization of Protein Complexes by Pattern Recognition
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:description:
Publisher Summary
               
                  As cryoelectron tomography of whole cells or cell sections approaches molecular resolution, it becomes feasible to locate protein complexes in cells by their distinctive three-dimensional (3D) structures alone, without the need of markers. This opens the door to the creation of molecular maps of cellular proteomes. The molecular map of a cell provides significant insights into the functional associations among macromolecular complexes that make up the operating modules of the cellular “factory.” Cryoelectron tomography of cells combines an optimal preservation of the sample with 3D imaging at molecular resolution and it provides faithful representations of the density landscapes inside cells. However, the interpretation of the tomograms is hampered by the low signal-to-noise ratio, which necessitates the use of powerful statistical pattern recognition techniques to map objects of interest in the images. In addition, template matching, in which the content of the sample volume is compared to the templates representing the molecules under consideration, shows great promises to achieve this goal.
